div.head: For the Spectator
div.summary: Urges voters to select candidates for justice of the peace based on their sensitivity to the needs of soldiers' families.

div.head: Sorghum as a Substitute for Bacon
div.summary: Praises the potential of sorghum to provide abundant harvests regardless of the weather.

div.head: Ex-President Pierce
div.summary: Notes that ex-President Franklin Pierce recently expressed sympathy for the Southern cause.
Brief report states that a New Jersey man was recently arrested for flogging a woman who he thought was his wife.

div.head: Is Sorghum Injurious?
div.summary: Cites report of a dentist to suggest that sorghum is harmful to the teeth.

page.pageNote: Classified ads, previously published court reports and conscription policy notice, columns 1-6; reports of skirmishing in Tennessee and Mississippi, column 7

div.head: The Spring Campaign
div.excerpt: "It is not well to be too confident, for the results of battles are very uncertain, and where there has been too much confidence, an unlooked for result is followed with a corresponding depression. We should guard against presumptuous confidence."
div.summary: Celebrates recent Confederate victories, but suggests that the people should remain cautious.

div.head: Failure to Exempt
div.summary: Suggests that the government extend religious exemptions to the recently conscripted soldiers over age 45 and under 18.

div.head: Meeting
div.excerpt: "The Ladies, (who are the main reliance in every good enterprise) it is hoped, will attend in full force."

transcript.p: A meeting will be held in the Court House of this place on next Tuesday night, May the 3d, for the purpose of forming an Association to aid the one formed in Richmond, for the benefit of the maimed soldiers of the Confederacy. This meeting will be addressed by the Rev. J. L. Stirewalt who has been very successful in other places in having Associations formed and in getting contributions for the purpose of supplying artificial limbs to our maimed soldiers. The meeting will also be addressed by Hon. A. H. H. Stuart & probably others. The Ladies, (who are the main reliance in every good enterprise) it is hoped, will attend in full force. Staunton should do more than any place yet visited by Mr. Stirewalt for this purpose. We believe it will. We pledge Augusta to do more than any county in the Valley.

div.summary: Announces that a meeting will be held next week for the purpose of forming an association to aid maimed soldiers. Rev. J. L. Stirewalt, who has formed similar organizations in other cities, and Alexander H. H. Stuart will address the meeting.

div.head: Oath of Allegiance
div.summary: Notes that a sermon was given in a Presbyterian Church in Lexington that explains why no Confederate citizen should feel obligated to take the oath of allegiance to the United States.

div.head: The Latest News
div.summary: Reports miscellaneous Confederate news, including the capture of ten Yankees down the Valley at Cedar Run last Sunday.

div.head: Capture of Plymouth, NC
div.summary: Tells about Confederate successes in Plymouth, North Carolina, which included taking 2,500 prisoners. Notes that a black Union soldier who disguised himself as a field hand was immediately hung as a spy.

div.head: Six Per Cent Bonds
div.summary: Corrects error from an article in last week's paper about six-percent bonds. The availability of these bonds will be more restricted than previously reported.

div.head: The "Reserves"

transcript.p: On Saturday last, the "Reserves" in this county were organized by forming companies and electing officers. Five companies were thus organized--four of them between the ages of 45 and 50, and one--an artillery company--of boys between the ages of 17 and 18 years.
The four companies of men elected the following as their officers:
J. F. Hottle, Captain; John Seawright, 1st Lieutenant; David W. Coiner, 2d do.; Wm. McFall, 3d do.
Robt. W. Stevenson, Captain; Wm. Blackburn, 1st Lieutenant; James W. Crawford, 2d do.; Wm. Morris, 3d do.
James C. Cochran, Captain; Thomas Coleman, 1st Lieut.; Peter R. Bright, 2d do.; Peter E. Houff, 3d do.
John Nunan, Captain; John Beard, 1st Lieutenant; J. C. Baum, 2d do.; G. K. Lewis 3d do.
The company of boys--a very fine looking company--elected the following officers:
J. C. Marquis, Captain; George A. Armentrout, 1st Lieutenant; Joseph S. Shumate, 2d do.; Chas. Stafford, 3d do.

div.summary: Announces the formation of five Augusta County reserve companies among men between ages 45 and 50, and between 17 and 18. For the First Company, the following were elected officers: J. F. Hottle, Captain; John Seawright, 1st Lieutenant; David W. Coiner, 2d Lieutenant; William McFall, 3d Lieutenant. For the Second Company: Robert W. Stevenson, Captain; William Blackburn, 1st Lieutenant; James W. Crawford, 2d Lieutenant; William Morris, 3d Lieutenant. For the Third Company: James C. Cochran, Captain; Thomas Coleman, 1st Lieutenant; Peter R. Bright, 2d Lieutenant; Peter E. Houff, 3d Lieutenant. For the Fourth Company: John Nunan, Captain; John Beard, 1st Lieutenant; J. C. Baum, 2d Lieutenant; G. K. Lewis, 3d Lieutenant. And for the Fifth Company, a company of boys: J. C. Marquis, Captain; George A. Armentrout, 1st Lieutenant; Joseph Shumate, 2d Lieutenant; Charles Stafford, 3d Lieutenant.

div.head: [Illegible] Campaign
div.excerpt: "They are, one and all, officers and men, impressed with the belief that the Yankees are about to make their final effort, and that if they fail they will no longer have anything more to fear from them."
div.summary: Reports that the Confederate army is hopeful for the impending campaign on the Potomac.

div.head: Raid into Westmoreland County
div.summary: Gives account of a Yankee raid in Westmoreland County in which 10,000 pounds of tobacco and slaves were seized.

div.head: Reserve Surgical Corps
div.summary: Reports that the Surgeon General has issued an order that will establish a reserve Surgical Corps.

div.head: Baggage of 52nd Regiment
div.summary: Reports that the extra baggage of the 52nd Virginia Regiment has been sent to Staunton and can be picked up by family members.

div.head: The Yankee Congress
div.summary: Suggests that the recent uproar over an Ohio Congressman's pro-Southern statements indicates that nearly half of the United States Congress is also with the South.

div.head: Valuable Recipes: A Cheap and Palatable Supper

transcript.p: An experienced house keeper has furnished for the GAZETTE, the following which was tried in our own culinary department, and proved to be good.

The following is good for adults but still better for children. Take one pint of milk, 1 egg, and two pints of water; boil the milk and water in separate vessels; beat the egg well in a quart bowl or cup, and pour upon it slowly the boiling milk, stirring briskly as you pour. When the egg and milk have been thoroughly mixed, pour them into the boiling water, stirring at the same time. Add 2 teaspoonfuls of salt, and let the mixture boil for a few minutes. In the meantime fill a half-gallon tureen or pan two thirds full of light bread, cut into slices or broken into fragments, and pour your boiling mixture over it. Double the quantity of milk and eggs would be better, if you can afford it, but the above is both agreeable and wholesome.

div.summary: Prints recipe for a supper of bread, milk, and water.

div.head: Yankee Brutality
div.summary: Tells about the murder of a Charlotte, North Carolina, man by Yankee soldiers invading his home.

div.head: Good Batter Cakes
div.summary: Gives recipe for batter cakes made of milk, eggs, and flour.
Reports that a Confederate picket learned from Yankee soldiers that General Grant had been sent to Virginia by Lincoln so that he could be humbled.
Notes that the "notorious" Parson Brownlow of Tennessee advises that all Southern men be driven out of the eastern part of that state.

div.head: Remarkable Revolutionary Prophecy
div.summary: Reprints predictions made in 1780 by a man named "Amindah," which include discussion of a "division" to take place in the United States in 1861.

div.head: On With the Dance
div.summary: Prints article from a Northern newspaper that condemns the balls and revelry taking place in the North.

div.head: Preserving Potatoes
div.summary: Offers suggestions for making a potato harvest last a full year.

div.head: A Picture of Yankeedom
div.summary: Prints excerpt from Northern newspaper that depicts the wartime society in that section as one big drunken carnival.

div.head: Exempting Farmers
div.excerpt: "This is right, and shows us that the authorities are anxious to foster the producing interests of the country."
div.summary: Expresses approval of the recent exemption of over sixty farmers from a conscript camp in Raleigh, North Carolina.

div.head: Listen Voters of Churchville District
div.summary: Urges Churchville district voters to support William B. Cochran in the upcoming election for justice of the peace.

div.head: Mr. Editor
div.summary: States that an advertisement from Ned Lilly and Charlie Marshall in the April 12 edition of the paper was a hoax. No one with those two names serves in Company F, 5th Virginia Infantry.

div.head: For the Spectator
div.summary: Urges Jacob Long to declare his candidacy for magistrate of the 9th district.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On April 21, Rev. Mr. Dice married George W. Hanger and Elizabeth Lotts at the M. E. Parsonage.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On April 25, Rev. Mr. Dice married Jacob Strickler and Elizabeth Lotts at the M. E. Parsonage.

div.head: Announcements
div.summary: Announces candidacy of John M. Hanger for magistrate in the New Hope district.

div.head: Organization of the Reserves
div.summary: Gives notice of the rules regarding the formation of reserve forces in Virginia counties such as Augusta.
